page.title: 11Local History from 1900
page.content: {Charles Kingsley,}author of the" Water Babies" spent his childhood in Clovelly as his father was rector until 1836.{Christine Hamlyn}was the best remembered Lord of the Manor for 52 years until 1936 and her initials C.H. appear on many restored Clovelly buildings. The{village school}dates from 1872 and was an all age school. It was full during the last World War with evacuees. It now has a roll of 30 children. In the 19th century Clovelly was a thriving port and {fishing village.} Many craft were built locally. At least 34 Clovelly men had ships masters certificates. They were mostly deep water men. There was also a flourishing coastal trade in limestone,culm and building stone as well as fishing. Now{tourism}is Clovelly's main industry.
